channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Syria photos 'contradict weapons claim'
item.description: As accusations fly over who may have unleashed chemical weapons in Syria, some are skeptical about whether a chemical assault happened at all.

item.title: Rebels, regime blame each other
item.description: The Syrian government and the opposition blame each other for an alleged chemical weapons attack. Nick Paton Walsh reports.

item.title: Bangladesh's president dies at 85
item.description: Bangladeshi President Mohammad Zillur Rahman died Wednesday at a Singapore hospital, where he was being treated for a lung infection, according to state-run media in Dhaka. He was 85.

item.title: Jordanian king's remarks spark uproar
item.description: Controversial remarks made by the Jordanian ruling monarch to an American magazine triggered a domestic media uproar and denials from the royal palace, just days before the U.S. president was scheduled to visit Jordan.

item.title: ISAF begins pulling out of Wardak
item.description: Afghan President Hamid Karzai in February accused U.S. forces of "torture" and "murder" in the restive Wardak province. Now Western powers will pull out of one of its districts after reaching an agreement with Karzai on the area's future.

item.title: Islamists claim Iraq anniversary attacks
item.description: An al-Qaeda affiliate claimed responsibility Wednesday for a chain of 24 bombings and two gun attacks in Iraq a day earlier, as the death toll rose to 61.

item.title: Al Qaeda letter details U.S., Europe plans
item.description: A previously secret document found at Osama bin Laden's compound in Pakistan sets out a detailed al Qaeda strategy for attacking targets in Europe and the United States.

item.title: Report: French hostage killed in Mali
item.description: A French hostage held in Mali has been executed by al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, Mauritania's ANI news agency reports.

item.title: UK royals head underground at Baker St.
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II is to head below ground Wednesday with Prince Philip and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, to mark the 150th anniversary of the London Underground.

item.title: N. Korea shows imagined 'U.S. attack'
item.description: A new North Korean propaganda video shows images of what appears to be an imagined missile attack on U.S. government buildings in Washington, including the White House and the Capitol.

item.title: Political candidate denies escort past
item.description: In one picture, the political candidate wears a bright blue business suit, standing with her arms crossed beside her campaign pledge to bring "hope for your family." In another, she wears white lace underwear and angel wings.

item.title: Hacked PCs falsify billions of ad clicks
item.description: Online investigators have exposed a network of hijacked computers that defrauded advertisers by generating billions of fake ad views.

item.title: Nadal urges tighter drugs control
item.description: Rafael Nadal has called for stricter doping controls and more transparency to help eradicate drug cheating in tennis.

item.title: AEK bans footballer for fascist salute
item.description: The Greek footballer who achieved global infamy on Saturday after celebrating a goal with a fascist salute has been barred by his club until the end of the season.

item.title: Beckham crowned soccer's top earner
item.description: David Beckham is the highest-paid soccer player in the world, according to prestigious magazine France Football.

item.title: Hope for Pakistan and Afghanistan
item.description: Peter Bergen says Pakistan is more stable than many think, and there are reasons for hope in Afghanistan

item.title: Why Obama's trip to Israel matters
item.description: This week, Barack Obama will embark on his first trip to Israel as president. The visit will enable him to engage, experience and touch Israelis in ways that move and bolster us.

item.title: Israel trip is 'smart politics'
item.description: Aaron David Miller says President Obama's attempt to repair relationship with Benjamin Netanyahu is smart politics.

item.title: Does China care about Hollywood?
item.description: When China's most successful homegrown movie went on international release last month, hopes were high that the slapstick comedy, which has drawn comparisons with "The Hangover," would blaze a trail for Chinese-language cinema.

item.title: Can pope change church?
item.description: Father Joseph McShane tells CNN's Christiane Amanpour whether Pope Francis has the background to reform

item.title: Peres: No doubt of U.S. support
item.description: Israel's president conceded Tuesday his country may disagree with the White House at times over Iran's nuclear progress, but said he is "free of doubts" that U.S. President Barack Obama would use military force if necessary to stop Tehran from developing a nuclear bomb.

item.title: Nuclear fusion: 'Perfect energy source'
item.description: Until recently, fears of peak oil and dependence on Middle Eastern suppliers were the key factors shaping our energy policy, pushing governments to scramble for fossil fuel alternatives. Then came shale gas, tar sands, and other unconventional sources. Industry found ways to affordably extract fuel for decades to come. So many are now imagining an end to the energy crisis. That's a dangerous mistake.

item.title: Did Iraq War give birth to Arab Spring?
item.description: I was living in Syria when the statues of Saddam Hussein in neighboring Iraq came toppling down.

item.title: Obama to Israel: U.S. proud to stand as strongest ally
item.description: Barack Obama arrives in Israel for the first time as U.S. president as part of a sweep across the Middle East, which will include visits to the West Bank and Jordan.

item.title: Livni: Clear chemical weapons in Syria
item.description: Israeli Justice Minister Tzipi Livni says "it is clear for us here in Israel" that chemical weapons have been used in Syria, and an international response to the crisis should be "on the table in the discussions between Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Obama" during the president's trip to Israel.

item.title: Israeli, Palestinian views of Obama
item.description: CNN's John King examines the changing public opinions of President Obama in Israel and the Arab world.

item.title: Israeli minister expects Kerry to return
item.description: Israeli Justice Minister Tzipi Livni said Wednesday that U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry plans to return to Israel after President Obama leaves, and she expects that he'll lay the groundwork to try to restart stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

item.title: Few expectations, many questions
item.description: The banners hanging on Israeli street corners boast of the "Unbreakable Alliance" with the United States, and the Stars and Stripes is flying side by side with the Star of David all across Jerusalem.

item.title: Peres 'trusts Obama' on Iran
item.description: Israeli President Shimon Peres believes Obama would use military force if necessary to prevent a nuclear Iran. CNN's John King reports.

item.title: Renewed euro fears after vote
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest explains the latest developments in the Cyprus bank crisis and what it means for the markets.

item.title: Outage paralyzes S. Korea computers
item.description: South Korean police investigate a computer outage affecting servers at leading TV broadcasters and banks, prompting the military to step up its cyber alert level.

item.title: Who's responsible for outage?
item.description: Computer outages hits broadcaster and banks in South Korea, as CNN's Matthew Chance reports.

item.title: U.S. flies B-52s over South Korea
item.description: The U.S. Air Force is breaking out some of its heaviest hardware to send a message to North Korea.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: Journey of 'girl withdancing horse'
item.description: Charlotte Dujardin became known as "The girl with the dancing horse" at the London Olympics, where she completed an incredible journey from low-paid stable girl to becoming the new star of dressage.

item.title: Plane campaign: Does sexy sell seats?
item.description: Many Asian airlines base their brand image on young, attractive flight attendants

item.title: Gangsta gardener of L.A. 'food desert'
item.description: As a lifelong resident of South Central Los Angeles, I refuse to be part of the social system that breeds problems rather than solutions. South Central is a "food desert" where the lack of healthy food alternatives leads to obesity and preventable disease.

item.title: For sale: 'Mona Lisa' of kitsch
item.description: With glossy hair, exotic outfit and pouting lips, she's the classic pin-up, except for that greenish-blue skin.

item.title: Psychedelic graffiti transforms ship
item.description: Welcome to the Duke of Lancaster. A hulking, rusting, abandoned ship on the Dee Estuary in north Wales, which has become a canvas for some of the most renowned graffiti artists from across Europe.

item.title: 'Africa's tallest building' planned
item.description: A $10 billion high-tech hub in Ghana could become home to Africa's tallest building, and bring global IT firms to the country.

item.title: Chinese 12 year-old to make golf history
item.description: Golf players just keep getting younger.

item.title: Brick kiln laborers freed in India
item.description: CNN's Mallika Kapur rides along on a raid in rural India as 140 bonded laborers are freed from a brick kiln.

item.title: New spoof Jobs biopic on way
item.description: Forget Ashton Kutcher and Aaron Sorkin. The next Steve Jobs biopic you see will star the "I'm a Mac" guy and come from the twisted minds of Funny or Die.

item.title: Google Maps climbs mountains
item.description: Google Maps' Street View is becoming less and less about photographing the road to grandma's house and more about getting you off the road entirely. The tech giant's latest project, unveiled Monday, takes mapping initiatives to new and extreme heights by offering interactive galleries of some of the world's tallest mountains.

item.title: Northern lights dazzle
item.description: They are one of nature's most spectacular sites: The aurora borealis, or northern lights as they are known, have captivated onlookers for thousands of years.

item.title: 'I want a better life'
item.description: A single mother who depends on the food bank fears her situation will only worsen with the latest UK benefit cuts.

item.title: When Travolta and Diana danced
item.description: Sumptuous velvet, delicate sequins, intricate beading: They are dresses fit for a princess -- Princess Diana, that is -- and if you've got a big pocketbook (with a designer label, naturally), they could be yours.

item.title: $3 yard sale bowl sells for $2.2M
item.description: A rare Chinese bowl bought for about $3 from a yard sale in the U.S. sold for $2.2 million at an auction in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: China's workforce at a crossroads
item.description: China's extraordinary climb to the world's second largest economy was built on the back of Chinese workers, many of whom left rural farms to migrate for work in coastal factories.

item.title: Video targets White House
item.description: An animated video purportedly produced in North Korea puts Washington, D.C., in crosshairs. Barbara Starr reports.

item.title: Malala defies Taliban with books
item.description: After being shot in the head, teenage blogger Malala Yousafzai has done what her Taliban attackers so despise. She returned to school.

item.title: Architect Ito's unusual buildings
item.description: Seoul-born, 71-year-old Japanese Toyo Ito is this year's recipient of architecture's most coveted prize.

item.title: New jet vies for sky supremacy
item.description: Bombardier is not a name many associate with commercial flight. The Canadian plane manufacturer, which for years has based its business on its smaller, regional jets, has not traditionally been in a position to challenge the likes of Airbus and Boeing when it comes to providing larger carriers.

item.title: A high-tech hunt for pirates
item.description: On board the HDMS Iver Huitfeldt, the captain has just had them execute what on land would be considered a three point turn.

item.title: Open Mic: How life changed in Iraq
item.description: A decade after their country was torn apart by fighting, Iraqis step up to CNN's Open Mic and share their thoughts 10 years after coalition forces invaded.

item.title: Britain's beer tax puts pinch on pint
item.description: Britain's beer tax is rising quickly, making the price of a pint more dear than ever. Jim Boulden explores the revenue calculus.

item.title: Bremer: Iraq is better off
item.description: Former U.S. Administrator in Iraq Paul Bremer

item.title: Jamaica's sled legend gets sequel
item.description: "Jamaica, we have a bobsled team," cried the Hollywood film that immortalized an unlikely quartet of Winter Olympians who became the story of the 1988 Games. It planted a seed in the brain of another Jamaican who, 22 years later, began his quest to ski at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi.

item.title: Oprah explains 'paying it forward'
item.description: Media mogul Oprah Winfrey has redefined what it means to be successful and "pay it forward." Felicia Taylor reports.

item.title: Opinion: Why the Iraq War was for oil
item.description: CNN Exclusive: Antonia Juhasz, author of "The Bush Agenda," says Big Oil were the winners of the Iraq War -- and that the plans to open up Iraq's oil fields were designed years before the invasion.

item.title: News anchor reads own proposal
item.description: TV anchor tricked into announcing her own marriage proposal. CNN's Jeanne Moos lifts the veil on this teleprompter tale.

item.title: UK's poor bank on food aid
item.description: Every morning Lorna Sculley wakes up unsure whether she will be able to feed her children.

item.title: Photos: Explosion of color in the sky
item.description: They are one of nature's most spectacular sites: The aurora borealis, or northern lights as they are known, have captivated onlookers for thousands of years.

item.title: 2011: Who really killed Daniel Pearl?
item.description: CNN's Brian Todd looks at a report with details on the killing of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.

item.title: Amputee built finger from bike parts
item.description: A man who lost his finger in an accident developed a prosthetic finger that gives full functionality to the wearer.

item.title: Short game: Golf gets snappy makeover
item.description: To the casual onlooker golf is often perceived as behind the times due to the archaic rules and regulations which govern the game.

item.title: Punished for truth?
item.description: Army Chief of Staff Eric Shinseki lost his job for raising concerns about U.S. preparedness in Iraq, professor says.

item.title: Birth defects rise in Fallujah
item.description: Hospitals are seeing more deformities and birth defects among Iraqi children, reports CNN's Arwa Damon.

item.title: Did Bush, Blair commit war crimes?
item.description: George Bush and Tony Blair fabricated a threat in Iraq and should be tried for war crimes, writes lawyer Michael Mansfield in an opinion piece.

item.title: Why Arab world must talk about sex
item.description: Fear that any move toward greater personal freedom -- especially sexual freedom -- will lead to a free-for-all and a violation of Islamic principles is holding Egypt back from democracy, writes Shereen El Feki.

item.title: 'I would rather he was dead than arrested'
item.description: There were eight of them brandishing Kalashnikovs. They stormed through the door and blindfolded him.

item.title: Cyprus: What next?
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest explains the latest developments in the Cyprus bank crisis and what it means for the markets.

item.title: Syria weapons
item.description: As accusations fly over who may have unleashed chemical weapons in Syria, some are skeptical about whether a chemical assault happened at all.

item.title: Obama in Israel
item.description: For the first time as president, Barack Obama is making his first trip to Israel as concerns about Iran's nuclear progress percolate.

item.title: N. Korea
item.description: A new North Korean propaganda video shows images of what appears to be an imagined missile attack on U.S. government buildings in Washington, including the White House and the Capitol.

item.title: Michael Phelps
item.description: CNN's Pedro Pinto speaks with swimming great Michael Phelps, who retired after the 2012 London Games.

item.title: Kitsch pin-up
item.description: With glossy hair, exotic outfit and pouting lips, she's the classic pin-up, except for that greenish-blue skin.

item.title: $2.2M bowl
item.description: A rare Chinese bowl bought for about $3 from a yard sale in the U.S. sold for $2.2 million at an auction in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps geothermal potential
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: Sri Lanka's mass elephant migration
item.description: Poachers have decimated elephant populations across Africa and parts of Asia, killing thousands of animals for their revered ivory.

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Xi Jinping has taken the center stage as China's undisputed paramount leader.

item.title: Li Keqiang named Chinese premier
item.description: Li Keqiang on Friday was named China's premier, the No. 2 position in the Chinese government, completing the once-a-decade transition of leadership in the world's most populous nation.

item.title: Chinese farm claims dead pigs
item.description: A Chinese farm admitted to dumping dead pigs into Huangpu River, which had about 6,000 bloated carcasses pulled from its water this week, state media reported.

item.title: Will China finally 'bite' North Korea?
item.description: North Korea, China's longtime ally, has vexed Beijing for years with its rocket launches, nuclear tests, kidnapping of Chinese fishermen and other erratic behavior. Yet, Beijing has run interference at the United Nations to temper punishments against Pyongyang, and has even helped Pyongyang circumvent sanctions.

item.title: Coca-Cola probed over mapping
item.description: The government of a remote province in western China says it is investigating Coca-Cola over allegations that it illegally mapped parts of the province, as China and the US engage in an escalating war of words over cyber espionage.

item.title: Inflation warning from central bank
item.description: China must be "on high alert" against inflation, central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Wednesday, striking a hawkish tone at his most important news conference of the year.

item.title: Artist Ai Weiwei to release album
item.description: Dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, whose artwork is shown in museums around the world, is taking a different direction with his latest project -- a heavy metal album.

item.title: World's biggest mall a 'ghost town'
item.description: They built it, but the shoppers didn't come.

item.title: Report: Chinese military hacking
item.description: The Chinese government is sponsoring cyber-espionage to attack top U.S. companies, according to Grady Summers, vice president of security firm Mandiant.
